condition and let me just talk to you a bit about that which is typically when you have the ddmm YY uh kind of format
when you write the out uh write output into S3 typically the first character is what
is used as an an entry point into the S3 buckets and so what happened was because
say we had from 10th march to 17th March that was the week of data that was available we had just one entry point
that was one right and this became an issue we could have the mm and y y are
not changing in the in our file format so we are having an issue that we have just one entry point and we have a large number of files so we are hitting a
raise condition scenario so one of the things that we needed to do and one of the things that are very critical here
is to have an hash key generator we did a simple hash key generator where we actually took we took a standard date
we actually took January 1st 2010 as a standard date and any date file that you
take you look at the number of days since the start of the January 1 2010 so
you took say today minus the number of days you find out the number of days and you did a modulo 35 operation on that
the Modo 35 operation will come out with what the day index will be and now instead of having one day index you
could potentially have up to 35 day indexes or one or two or three right and
we also then went so we said okay we have 35 entry points which is very good we've said let's do a second iteration
which we'll once you have got into the day you can also have other sub entry points and we created the week index so
we did the same thing we found out the number of days we did a Modelo 7 so we found out the week and then we did a
Model 35 and found out a new index in terms of what is the weak index also So
based on this we were actually able to create a fairly large index format but what you will interestingly note is that
the first character was now 35 entry points this actually helped us increase
the number of entry points into the S3 output and this was fairly critical um because we were noticing that once we
